A bit unrelated but does anyone have any easy way to setup NodeJS on a server? Basically, I'm looking for a cheap suitable server and a guide of some sorts to drop in a website based on NodeJS
<@U09T8SFG8>: it should be relatively easy
install node
then run the script :see_no_evil:
I am a total noob in anything web
No I'm looking more like a cheap hosting
like barebones
Ubuntu server?
<@U09T8SFG8>: both azure and amazon have services for exactly that
and heroku too

```
curl -sL <https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_5.x> | sudo -E bash -
sudo apt-get install -y nodejs
```
pretty easy :smile:
I believe azure is probably more beginner friendly as it is like a checkbox
Digital Ocean has One-Click App with NodeJS
Elastic Beanstalk in AWS is also pretty decent
^ a few other services resale amazon and azure as well with similar offerings

Hello Guys! Anyone has a link to android development exercises or project exercises that one could tell someone looking for a job to do within 3hrs for basic, intermediate and advance level android development

lol :smile: I have a love/hate relationship with Samsung.
Anyhow you should just ignore Samsung and act like your assessment project works on anything :smile:
I think you can use that one for all 3 levels and the difference in code will usually be obvious
Jup

1. no libs (:no_mouth::gun:)
2. Retrofit
3. MVP+Retrofit
4. MVP+Dagger+Retrofit
5. MVP+Dagger+Retrofit+Rx
I wish I knew Kotlin before I went on interview here. Would be funny if you write the project in Kotlin and nobody on the team knows it xD

but still

:smile:
Within 3 hours, it’s abit of a stretch to get all the pieces together I think :simple_smile:
MVP+dagger makes your tests so easy

and if they use Fresco just kick them out immediately

the adapter logic is missing

pass a string to the detail activity
something like that with some minor trivial logic missing

i mean different question for each level. that would be too cheap for an advance person <@U0K1ALDQE>
<@U0TDWTPBL>: any take-home assignment should not take more than 2-3 hours because at that point it becomes a paid app :stuck_out_tongue:
I would say the beginner to advanced has to do with the quality of code
you just want to be sure that whoever takes it knows stuffs according to the his level
I wouldn’t give an assignment to an advanced dev
above mid-level, architectural questions would be better
I would ask for some code for me to view
and discuss it with him. Discuss techniques, patterns, etc etc
what <@U0K1ALDQE> is saying, having someone explain his choices on existing code is the best bet on figuring out if he knows what he's doing
yeah. we just want it to be a form of an exam where you get to build something that won’t take more than 3hrs
For advanced stuff. It’s hard to think of something
If they handled the lifecycle events - they probably know what they’re doing.
You can not give him an advanced project and expect him to fill in functionality or add features
Because it might take him time to get familiar with the code
Like I said where I did my interview, there was a project with stuff left out
A beginner like I was, can finish the app in 4-6 hours.
We take the person out to lunch to test how he is as a person
If it’s some1 advanced we either don’t let him to the project, because he can prove his skills through showing code and discussions
Or we have him come late. And also take him out for lunch
You can really notice the difference between a beginner and some1 advanced

my suggestions would be:

- make it simple enough, don’t even need web data, just some sample test cases
- plenty of suggestions over at hackerrank and similar sites, pick one, change the wording and adapt to your needs
the tests bit is crucial, a real nice sift
we used an adaptation of mars rover kata, but really any such exercise should work

hey everyone, I want to update a server with some step data recorded using GoogleFit. I want to be able to periodically update the server every hour or so with some data. Exploring some Android components, it's either a background `Service`, or an `IntentService` with an `AlarmManager` or even `SyncAdapter`. Any thoughts?
Heads up regarding AlarmManager: many phones now block it as their “ultra power saving technology” (pointing at Samsung)
ah :disappointed:
<@U0ZKWJ8KW|fernandogalloro> has joined the channel
And I am paying the price as we speak :cry: Have to implement push notifications in an old project because of allot of complaints regarding notifications not coming.
I dont really know if you have any other options, though. :simple_smile:
So if I have to periodically upload data in the background, an `IntentService` with an `AlarmManager` to wake it up is the best option?
<@U0ZJSJ9R9|stewartfortier> has joined the channel
To be honest, I’m confused where the `SyncAdapter` has its place in this problem
It doesnt, actually.
what’s you minsdk?
if it’s 21 jobscheduler could do the trick
the `AlarmManager` would only be responsible for triggering the `SyncAdapter`
<@U053PPGDC>: MinSDK is 16
no jobscheduler then
<@U0QR1SM32>: Makes sense
unless you have 2 implementations -> one w/ AlarmManager & other w/ JobScheduler
When would you use a `SyncAdapter` then? I always thought that was for updating things in the background
if you have sqlite + content provider and want to sync data with a server
a sync adapter is for when you have data in devices and data in the server and want to make sure you keep the updated one
i use it to handle my oauth refreshing
so if device is updated it uploads if is outdated it downloads
I never really liked that API :stuck_out_tongue:
same
<@U0F5VSCNA>: Take a look at GMS `PeriodicTask`
<https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/gcm/PeriodicTask>
Yeah the `GcmNetworkManager` that `PeriodicTask` uses has allot of the magic built in.
<@U0F5VSCNA> <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-3ry8PxcJJA>

attachments.text: [Title text] "If that doesn't fix it, git.txt contains the phone number of a friend of mine who understands git. Just wait through a few minutes of 'It's really pretty simple, just think of branches as...' and eventually you'll learn the commands that will fix everything."

text: i mean if you are a masochist then yes but I already have something like 14 modules so —info is like saying ‘hey gradle, please print 1 million lines of text even though I really just need to know where you failed but after you fail please print 10000 lines of shit I dont want to read because you are such an amazing build system'
that would just end up telling me that the command that ran aapt failed with non zero
yea not really a gradle issue though. just a poor feedback loop from the external tool
makes me wish the entire toolchain ran in process with gradle
maybe
or maybe it just isn’t a good idea for a build system
so much better than ant or maven
and make
—stacktrace is generally hilarious with 4-5 top level exceptions that each have 70+ method references
debugging my ant problems took seconds
yeah it doesnt have all the features by comparison but it did everything quite sensibly
maven as well

gradle, well you need to put it into a debugger but you cant without manually bringing up a debugger cause tooling is not important to the gradle team or jetbrains.. not sure which but whatever you can’t just simply click a button and debug
not counting that typically the IDE is useless at figuring out what you are doing because so much of gradle relies on runtime to actually work
rootProject.nopeIDontKnowWhatYouWantEvenThoughItsRightThereInThatFile
JavaScript would be a better build system.. no it probably already IS a better build system
likely uses less memory too

Guys, is adding a view programmatically inside a `recyclerview viewholder` an efficient solution instead of having nested ones?
Throw in the groovy bastard child as a comparison, it's not really a competitin
instead of nested views or nested view holders?
What do you mean exactly <@U0SNJDQDC>
Cause that can mean a lot of things
Currently I have a parent `recyclerview` (ie. category title) which has another `recyclerview` inside it (for the category items), but it seems like its too complicated
oh yes do not do that

recyclerview items have a type id that you can use to identify which viewholder/view to use for a given position. Aka the nested reyclers is redundant as you are solving what recyclerview already solves.

<http://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v7/widget/RecyclerView.Adapter.html#getItemViewType(int)>
Because I need to manipulate things for the child items as well. Like moving them to another category etc
I was able to make it work by `notifyitemchanged` for every tick listener I registered for each rows
But yeah. It's pretty messy
Okay I'll look into that <@U055GGAHS>
if you have a single recycler you can use item ids combined with the types to handle animating positions properly as moving a data element from one set to another can be moved properly
The UI requirement here is to have a cardview for each parent category
Maybe I over-thought about this
you want lists inside a cardview?
yeah
this is a shitty answer but do not do that
<https://www.google.com/design/spec/components/cards.html#cards-content>

attachments.title: Cards - Components - Google design guidelines
attachments.fallback: Google design guidelines: Cards - Components - Google design guidelines

text: <@U0SNJDQDC|aimanb> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/aimanb/F0ZS0EM96/anatomy.jpg|anatomy.jpg> and commented: what I'm trying to achieve here. just a sketch

initial_comment.comment: what I'm trying to achieve here. just a sketch

text: Cards are not meant to hold complex lists. They ‘can’ hold a list but it sounds like you are using cards to hold content that is related to content in other cards.
Yes it is kinda complex. But i'll try to make it not messy technically.
<@U055GGAHS|ian.shaun.thomas> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/ian.shaun.thomas/F0ZSDFD2N/screen_shot_2016-04-11_at_11.45.47_pm.png|Not quite what you want but for instance>

file.title: Not quite what you want but for instance

text: <@U055GGAHS|ian.shaun.thomas> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/ian.shaun.thomas/F0ZQLPUPM/components_cards_content2.png|Example of when it is okay to have lists in cards>

file.name: components_cards_content2.png
file.title: Example of when it is okay to have lists in cards

text: cards should not be longer than the length of the screen imo
Hmm
<@U0546QERR>: actually they cover that too
having a recyclerview kinda makes me think you'll have pretty long content
cards should actually not be bigger than the screen and should have nested scrolling in very specific situations
Yea that was the design mockup i need to follow. Oh god why
Thanks anyway for the input
err I was wrong its not nested scrolling.. cards can expand past the view height at the users request
but that doesnt really help you either way
if you do go with the nested recycler views look into doing the recycler pool yourself so you can share the view holders between all the nested recyclers
for reference <http://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v7/widget/RecyclerView.html#setRecycledViewPool(android.support.v7.widget.RecyclerView.RecycledViewPool)>

Hello, guys. I need to make a google maps markers grouping and I read that I should use <https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-api/utility/marker-clustering#simple> (clusters). The info is straightforward but is there an easy way to know which markers are close to each other so I can group them with cluster?

Because in the example they are using a list of markers with hard coded data and they know that they are close to each other. But I have a bunch of markers which can be from different cities even countries and I am not sure how I can group them correctly
